text:
PROFESSOR: The first step
of making architecture
is to visit the site.

It's the site that gives us
clues as to how to design.

Of course, we have
a program, and we
have thoughts about form.

But it's really the
site that is the most

important at the
beginning stage.

In fact, we should know the site
as well as we our own backyard.

The site is our friend for the
whole process of designing.

It's what we keep returning to,
keep understanding, seeing it

during the day, at night,
in the rain, in the sun.

It's the giver of
the original ideas.

Of course, the program and
the forms and all the rest

is important, but it's
the site that starts it.

So what you're about
to see is a site visit

to the North End,
which is where we're

doing a project for design of a
house on the sides of buildings

and on the roofs
of the buildings.

And then later, in the
same area, the same site,

we will be designing
a community space.

So the following is that
first visit to the site.
[CITY NOISES]
What do you think?
AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE]
PROFESSOR: Huh?
Challenging.

You can see the church
from here, the nave of it,
through there.

Yeah, I think if you
knocked on the door,

and you could probably see
the inside of that window.

There's a church and monastery
or school there, I think.
I think it's connected.

And, of course, you're
on the roof of it.

You got to attach yourself to
the side of that [INAUDIBLE]

AUDIENCE: Yeah, it's
[INAUDIBLE] a little bit
that it [INAUDIBLE]

PROFESSOR: Yeah, so it's
going to be hanging off.

And we do have to think
about how structure

is going to work in
some general way,

and we'll get
David Whitney back.

Sometimes you're going
to cantilever out.

Sometimes there's
going to be braces.

You could run things
down to the ground.

You have no limitations
of what you can do,
but we do want to be structural.

You could hang over the
side, and structurally, it
would hold on.

For instance, who has
the vent site that--

two vents but the one
that hangs over it?
AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE]
PROFESSOR: OK, both of them.
No--
AUDIENCE: It lands off the side.

PROFESSOR: Yours is on the
side, and one hangs over, yeah.
AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE]

PROFESSOR: So that one
could hang over almost
like a shelf coming over.

The other one is going to
attach itself to the side.

What can anybody see from here
that relates to our problem?

AUDIENCE: I think if-- like
of you have [INAUDIBLE]..
PROFESSOR: Say again?

AUDIENCE: This-- as far as a
problem with having a place

where you have a family, this is
literally a playground and you
could--
AUDIENCE: Yeah, over there.
PROFESSOR: Right, and we--

however, later, right
across the street,

that's our job is to design
a place for us to be,
which would include a--
could include a playground.
That's our site.

Right here where that playground
is is part of our site
but also all that area in there.

And certainly, this
is a place also
that could be used that way.

This has a special
meaning, and that's

part of your site
clueing, finding out

why it's here, why all
the buildings are here
for that matter.
What else do you see?
Look around.
Quick, behind me.

AUDIENCE: It's got
a lot of height.
PROFESSOR: Huh?

Yeah, someone's done what
we're doing, very modestly.

Oh, they've added already
in a way on top of the roof.
AUDIENCE: And on the side.

PROFESSOR: And on
the side, yeah.

So they've done sort
of what we're doing
but in a very conservative way.

I'm not suggesting
you be conservative.

I do think if you went
down to Paul Revere's Mall

and go to the Old
North Church and look

at that one that's
hanging on the side,

it's more interesting
architecturally.

And it's interesting
because I think
it fits into the North End.

So part of the issue of this
project, like the Quarry,

is how you fit what you're
doing into the context.

But now the context is
different, obviously.

But it doesn't mean it has to be
brick and clone-y or whatever.

We are sitting on the dock of
the water, of the old water.

I think somebody might find
this out as part of your clue,

but this is the original site
when the water was right there.

As you may know-- may I have
that drawing just for a second?

That's why this street
is curved because that

used to be-- in fact, I think
it still-- it says North Street.

It was the original
street along the dock.
So this was all water.
This was solid.

And you know, Boston,
over the years,
is filled in tremendously.
All Back Bay is filled.
All South End is filled.
All Cambridge is filled.
Where we are is all filled also.

So it's a habit of cities to
do that, to fill up the water.

What about the person
that's got this one up here?
[INTERPOSING VOICES]
PROFESSOR: Phil, Philip.
He's got an interesting issue.

How does he make a
form up there that
relates to that little curve?
Or does he?

That's a context issue
just like the Quarry.
What does he do?

But he could relate to
that, and at the same time,

the top of it, the
sky form that we

talk about could be
something entirely different.

So it's the same
issues as before.

Landform, but the land is up
in the sky, and the middle,
and the sky.

And the sky can be
something quite different.
It doesn't have to be the same.

What I don't want you to do is
to try to, as in the Quarry,
imitate the context.

We are trying to add
something that relates
but not necessarily the same.

Otherwise, you end up with
little kind of Walt Disney,

colonial, whatever stuff,
which is not the issue.

It does, as you
can see, our site,

which is over there
for the community,

is quite a bit lower
than where we are.

Not quite a bit,
but lower than this

and then lower still
than over here.
It's going uphill slightly.

Now, this area is what we'd
like to build the [? eighth ?]

scale out of cardboard, which
is the equivalent to our Quarry.

But instead of a place,
now we have a path.

We're relating to each
end of the street.

On the other hand, I
suggest that you probably,

when you're done
building, almost everybody
can wave to somebody.

She can wave to
Phillip and Stacey.

So there'll be little
sub communities.

If you're close
together in a site,

you're welcome to
explore connections.

This is like the Quarry,
and you now are detectives.

A good architect, in my
opinion, starts with the site.
This is our site.

So you want to learn as much
as you can about the site.

And there are different
kinds of information.

Obviously, there's
architectural form.

You probably can find any kind
of form you want in this site.

In fact, there's a little
surprise around the corner--

if you haven't seen it--
of a little guy sticking--
do you see it on the corner--

sticking on the side,
a little bay window.

There's all kinds of
bay windows up there.

So form and materials is one
clue that we're looking for.

But equally important, is
people and what they're doing.
What's happening here?

Look at what's happening
right around us.

There are tourists
from Iowa and Ohio

and all over the
country walking around.
But there are also residents.

You can almost tell the
difference, who's who.

On weekends, you'll find
kids playing in the street.

You go to the Paul Revere
Mall this afternoon,

and you may find kids and
tourists going through.
So it's a mixture.
You're adding to that mix.

Be good to know something
about who your neighbors are,

even though we're
building in this canyon

because the next problem
of the community place

is how to bring everybody
together, including yourself.
There are other clues.
There's historic clues.
What's the history?
Why is this place--

why is the North End
like the North End?

What makes it different
than the Back Bay?
Why?
Why are the streets like this?

I know why, but you
should find out.
So there's history of the place.
Those are clues.
There's real clues.

Philip was probably
going to bring back
somebody steps or something.

You don't have to
bring something back.

Why don't you bring
back is what I

call a clue, which is something
in your head or something
physically.

So once again, when
we're back in the studio,

we can visualize the site as
well as your own backyard,
like the Quarry.

It's the same thing,
except it's different.

So you start to think about how
you're going to add something

to the-- and I'm using
this one as an example--

to the side of that building
through some sketches.

It seems to me that this person
has to do something vertically.

The house is going to be on
several levels, I would think.

There's a limit to how far
you can cantilever off.

Whereas, on top of this
roof, it could be horizontal.

Phillip, up there, could
be horizontal and vertical.
He's not the highest.

And who has the one right
next to our community space?

Not the ventilator
tower, but over there.
AUDIENCE: It's like one?
PROFESSOR: One.
AUDIENCE: This one?
That's Kelly.
PROFESSOR: Yeah.
AUDIENCE: Kelly.

PROFESSOR: Kelly,
oh, that's right.
Kelly has that one.

That one is important
because she kind of overlooks
the whole area.

She's going to be
the person who's

going to be kind of the
gatekeeper of our community
area later.
Who has number 12?

12 is an interesting one
because you're on the roof

and you're over the side,
and you're a little bit

on the outer limits
of our community.

Almost everybody else
forms some communities.
That one does too.
It connects with three.
Who is three?

So there's a little connection
between the two of you.
And who's 13?
You're 13?

So there's a community
of 12, 13 and 3.
They're very close.

OK, what I'd like to have
do is have a good time.
Talk to--

AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE]
by the way?
PROFESSOR: I'll show you.

But I would like to ask
you just kind of nose

around, talk to people, look
and see what you can bring back.

See how many
different things you

can find that might influence
what you're designing.
That's one.

The second is to go to
Paul Revere's Mall, which

is the next street
over, which is Hanover.

And go up Hanover about
two or three blocks,

and it's on your left
by the fire station.

Go through Paul Revere's
Mall to the North Church.
That's where the lanterns were.

On the other side to the right,
you've got to go all the way up

to the Paul Revere's--
sorry, the North Church,

and then come back
along the other side.

You'll find a little
quiet courtyard,

and find that building
that I spoke about that
is hanging off the side.
So that's two things.

But walk around, enjoy yourself,
and have a cannoli or coffee.
